newsitem.title: FRANCE: Shamir criticises Weizman over Arafat meeting.
newsitem.headline: Shamir criticises Weizman over Arafat meeting.

text.p: Israeli ex-premier Yitzhak Shamir criticised President Ezer Weizman on Tuesday for meeting Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, saying he disagreed especially if Weizman wanted to put pressure on Israel's government.

Shamir, who turns 81 next month, also dismissed reports that he had been taken ill in the French capital last week. He only admitted grudgingly: "Maybe I was a bit tired but that can happen to everyone."

Commenting on Tuesday's meeting between the Palestinian president and the left-leaning Weizman in the Mediterranean coastal resort of Caesarea, Shamir told reporters: "I don't know the details but he (Weizman) should not have done this.

"Some newspapers say Weizman wanted to put pressure on (Israel's right-wing) government to force it to come to an agreement with Arafat. I can't understand how an Israeli president can do such a thing and use such means," Shamir said.
"I know Weizman well, I have esteem for him and like him but I disagree with what he did," said Shamir, the hardline prime minister of Israel from 1986 to 1992.
Visiting Weizman's private home, a beaming Arafat struck all the right chords, pledging that "negotiations will be the tool to resolve our differences".

Shamir, on a European fund-raising tour for the Jewish National Fund (Keren Kayemet), was also critical, though more guardedly, of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for having met Arafat on two separate occasions.
"I think what was required could have been done without meeting Arafat but I don't want to criticIse him (Netanyahu). Now it is done and one can still correct a lot of mistakes."
Netanyahu is a successor to Shamir as head of the right-wing Likud party and began his political career under Shamir.
The former premier also said the Palestinian Intifada uprising in the occupied territories would have petered out had he remained in power.
"In the last year of my government in 1992, it was already nearly liquidated." Asked how international opinion would have reacted, Shamir replied: "The world accepts facts."
The former Jewish underground fighter and spymaster said the Oslo agreements between Israel and the Palestinians "were solely aimed at turning over parts of the Land of Israel to our enemies."

He said Israel had been wrong to withdraw from major Arab centres in the West bank and Gaza Strip and should never leave the contested city of Hebron. "It is a holy Jewish city and we should not turn it over to our enemies. I hope many Jews will go to live there," he said.
